video.title: Kingdom Come: Deliverance II | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
Man, I was a lot harsher back when I was a 
punky, youthful, hot-headed 35-year-old. I

was looking back at my old review of Kingdom 
Come: Deliverance, and I was really down on it

from the word &quot;go,&quot; firstly for being a classic 
example of dry heave unnecessary colon titling.

I keep saying subtitles have no business on 
anything but sequels. But now there is a sequel,

so the universe has officially righted itself. 
The Plague Tale: Innocence Pokémon has evolved

and become a Plague Tale: Requiem. So let&#39;s 
take a look at the new sequel—urgh—Kingdom Come:

Deliverance 2. Fuck&#39;s sake. It&#39;s like we missed 
the point, and then we turned around and missed

a completely different point. Like a very lucky, 
oblivious person on an archery range. Kingdom Come

2 continues the story of Henry, a meaty, young lad 
from early 15th century Bohemia from a burnt-down

village in, going by his accent, whatever the 15th 
century Bohemia equivalent of the West Country is.

Henry&#39;s in a sort of administrative grey area 
of feudal society in that he is a peasant but

he&#39;s also the acknowledged bastard son of a 
lord, so he is permitted to talk to nobles,

and they&#39;re not allowed to execute 
him just for looking at them funny.

He&#39;s dispatched to a neighboring fiefdom to 
help his mate deliver a message from their

dads to the local lord to see where he is on the 
whole bloody &quot;conflict dividing the land&quot; thing,

and the job needs two guys because those wax 
seals can get pretty weighty, and his mate is

a nobleman and therefore refuses to lift anything 
heavier than a chambermaid&#39;s skirt. On the road,

they get attacked by bandits, robbed of 
everything, and then can&#39;t complete their

mission because nobody believes they&#39;re nobles as 
they aren&#39;t wearing the requisite peacock feathers

and arrogant sneer. Essentially, this is the bit 
at the start of a Metroid sequel where Samus gets

an atomic-powered intergalactic wedgie to explain 
why she has to run around picking up all her shit

again. Because the first act of Kingdom Come: 
Delivering The Mail retreads much of the process

we went through in the first game, starting out 
as a peasant with not even a moldy potato to

our name and having to work our way up the social 
ladder before we can get to the cool &quot;swordfights

on horses&quot; shit, learning many interesting 
things about medieval history as we go.

One of the first things we learn, for example, 
is that every single person in medieval times is

a complete prick. I guess it&#39;s hard to be a ray of 
sunshine when the Norwegians have just invaded and

the bubonic plague has killed your 12-year-old 
wife. The second thing we learn about medieval

peasant life is that it&#39;s really fucking boring. 
The only thing I could find to do to start saving

up for an actual shirt to replace my spunk-riddled 
burlap sack and finally have a fighting chance

with the fucking charisma checks was to take up 
blacksmithing. A minigame consisting of hitting

a metal thing with a hammer. For fucking ages. 
And you have to keep moving the thing around,

so you can&#39;t just zone out for it. Jesus Christ. 
Desert Bus did that as a fucking joke. And then

the game&#39;s all like, &quot;Ooh, why not try swinging 
the hammer in time with the tune your character&#39;s

whistling? Have fun with it?&quot; Bitch, that didn&#39;t 
work when my parents made me dust my bedroom,

and it&#39;s not gonna work now. You see, Kingdom 
Come is an immersive open world in the style

that always seems to get Kickstarter 
donators frothing at the wallets. Oh,

the realism. Go anywhere. Do anything. Every NPC 
has an agenda. They go to bed at night and won&#39;t

like you if you&#39;ve got nits, so you have to dunk 
your head in every horse trough you pass like

a newborn vampire who hasn&#39;t figured out why 
his hair keeps catching fire during the day.

Such games tend to be appreciable from a broad 
perspective but fall apart in the fine details.

The sheer number of interacting systems can go 
wrong in so many spectacular ways. Here&#39;s just

two from my playthrough: I had to reload a save 
because the story mission was to follow a platoon

of knights on horseback, but their pathfinding 
fucked up so the horses all stood in a circle,

sniffing each other&#39;s bums forever. And at one 
point, a distraught peasant woman beseeched me to

locate her missing daughter, for she was beside 
herself with worry. While said daughter was,

at that moment, sitting across the 
room, sewing some tea towels. But

my worst moments came when the game was 
operating completely as intended. Like,

at one point, I fail a speech check, and the 
dude decides he&#39;s gonna punch my lights out.

The combat is slightly better than the first 
game in that it actually functioned for me,

but it usually came down to parry, riposte, 
parry, riposte, stand on the other side of the

room talking shit while your stamina comes back, 
repeat, and I don&#39;t feel like a badass duelist,

I feel like I&#39;m trying to narrow down the thing 
that&#39;s making a really bad smell in my fridge.

But I manage to punch this dude enough that 
he runs away, but then he comes back with

fucking hammer, so I have to draw my sword and 
kill him, and we&#39;re in the middle of village,

so guards run over, I can&#39;t pay the fine and 
failed the speech check to blab my way out,

so I&#39;ve got three choices: murder the entire 
village, watch a prolonged cutscene of myself

being hanged before reloading my save, or 
reload my save now. I opted for the last one,

spoke to the dude again, passed the speech check 
this time, and parted as friends. Jesus Christ.

The road to cockup cascade is paved with realistic 
gameplay systems. You&#39;re told you can approach

problems with either stealth, combat, or 
diplomacy, but there&#39;s no point specializing

&#39;cos you&#39;ll get unavoidably stuck having to 
do all three at various times. The first game

soured me with mandatory combat; this one did it 
with mandatory stealth. The first several hours

of the game are spent trying to get invited 
to a wedding &#39;cos the lord&#39;s gonna be there

and you&#39;re hoping to convince him you&#39;re a noble 
by wafting caviar-scented farts in his direction,

but then oh! He doesn&#39;t show up. We&#39;ve been 
pissing you about this whole time, lol! Then

you get arrested and stripped of your stuff and 
locked in a castle with no option but to stealth

through densely populated, unfamiliar terrain 
where being spotted anywhere by anyone is instant

fail &#39;cos the guards descend like bees on a jam 
sandwich, then stealth all the way back out again.

You can knock guards out with special friendship 
hugs from behind, but half the time, they randomly

break out of the hug, so whoops, reload again. I 
asked Editor Nick for advice, as he seems to like

this game, and he said to just save scum. I CAN&#39;T 
SAVE SCUM, THEY TOOK ALL MY SAVE POTIONS, which

continues to be a gameplay feature as welcome as 
a scrubbing brush attachment on an endoscope. &quot;Are

you remembering to spend your perk points?&quot; 
Yes, of course I spent my perk points. What

kind of idiot doesn&#39;t spend their perk points? 
Then I hastily brought up the menu to figure out

where the fuck you spend perk points. Eventually, 
I found it. Three menus deep, tiny little text in

the middle of all the Renaissance-branded clutter, 
not that it made much difference in the end. I&#39;ll

admit Kingdom Come 2 occasionally came together, 
usually when railroading me through a plot event

that minimized the number of things that could 
fuck up, but whenever the leash comes off,

it&#39;s all so much pissing about. The bugs piss me 
about, the plot pisses me about, and in the end,

all I could do was piss about in return. 
Still, apparently you&#39;ll like it if you&#39;re

someone like Editor Nick. But what the fuck 
does he know? He still thinks I respect him.
